abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings show a satisfactory project
            outcome, likely sustainability, and modest institutional
            development impacts. Lessons learned address three main
            issues. First, a critical issue during preparation centered
            on the suitability of the instrument type to support the
            Government during its period of fiscal pressure: a
            multi-year investment loan was not adequate due to the need
            for a fast-disbursing mechanism, similarly was the case of
            an economic recovery loan, while the selected emergency
            recovery loan provided greater flexibility to ensure that
            social spending would not be reduced during the adjustment
            period. Second, while the loan delineated a number of policy
            reform actions sector wide - though appropriate - the
            breadth of the reform program did somehow detract the
            support to macroeconomic stability, and social efforts. It
            is thus suggested to consider in the future, a less
            comprehensive set of actions, particularly those not
            considered requirements for Board presentation, or
            effectiveness. Third, although the Government could have
            obtained additional resources from the International
            Monetary Fund (IMF), its entry at the time of the loan might
            have signaled investors with a much worse macroeconomic, and
            fiscal situation than anticipated; notwithstanding, the
            IMF's extension of its Staff Monitoring Program,
            favored more rigorous monitoring of the macroeconomic
            framework, providing an adequate coordination.
